with the marks of a number of returned quiz.z. He is liable to find
on one, Excellent, on another, Very Good, and on others; Good,
Good — or 4-, Not So Good, Sansfaaory, Fairly. Good, Fair, Unsatisfactory, 0. K., t' , Barely Passing, Bad. Poor, Very Poor, and,
we have heard of some cases of -Rotten.- Where does he stand in
regard to any of these courses?
In one course, four papers are returned. Three are listed Sans,
factory, the other Very Poor. How much was his margin Of safety
in the three Satisfactory papers? What was his mirk on the Very
Peer quiz? Ls he passing or failing the course? If, by some system
of magic unknown to us, he is able to determine what his mark is in
this particular subject, be has barely begun his task. An average
student takes five courses, and in this great game of mystifying
student, no two instructors mark alike. He must begin this
process of calculation anew. An 'Excellent," the zenith ...
course, may be paralleled by a a! in another subject Slide rules,
Monroe Cak-ulators, or higher forms of mathetnatics will avail 'o—
re:thing. The bark -Degree- is surely being badly tossed alvot •
the Sea of Uncertainty."
The claim is made against Our o- ld mode of operations
grades being given to papers, students worked 7.
and not with any intent of basetiring by cultural
the Subjects. This is a point which is well taken. There are
who, so long as their marks are 6. or :above, are content ts.
subjects take ,are of themselves, but, we cannot but feel.
every student in the university so minded, there are.num.:-:7- others
to whom the thought of "just passing" is a goad to more inc better
work. How can this better class of student, and it is for these we lift
9ur quill, possibly be inspired to more work in any course, when he
,tinot know how near he is to the brink?
The University of Wisconsin uses a system of marks whereby

improvement over our method in use today, if for no other reae..:11
than its uniformity, for what wail the numerous young instructssrs

unlimited. Yet, if A is to equal 100, and B,90 + or —, would it notbe just as easy to put down a 10 or a9 on the returned paper?
• Our present system has a double standard; that for the students
consumption as yet unnamed, that for the instructors use numerical.
Time is lost in the transformation from numerals to the wordy marks
we now receive But, and here is the rub, this double standard is'
not to be carried out in its entirety. There is to be a final aritlunetic
day of reckoning. Our marks are to be published in numerical form.
Can this be? Yes. But When? When it is too late. Once at the
time of giving of informal marks, a time through which we have just
_passed, which has molted this term in a tremendous increase in the
numbers of "informals" given, seeming to show that students, as a
whole, make worse grades and know less about their subjects when
not spurred on in quest of marks. The other instance is when the
sodaola-stic "grim reaper" takes his toll—and ar no times in—between
these dates are we allowed to steal a look into the Book of Judgement
and read the avt-ful truths contained therein. Why must there be
; this secrecy and with-holding of marks from their owners? Does this
system really benefit the student and help bun understand the more
cultural aspects of his courses?
Perhaps. this new system is but an intermediate step toward that
system of marking in which we will either pass or fail, and in which
oertain grades need not be offered for graduation. Even then, this
goal would ismalve manifold difficulties, such as the election to Phi
Beta Kappa, and admission to various professional schools. where'the
chief determinait is the marks obtained in college. If this system is
temporary it is also more than unsatisfactory to the majority of the
students on the campus, as any system involving a double standard of
marking, and breeding uncertainty in the undergraduate mind needs
must be.
P. W. N.
